text:
Hey everyone!
I'm having some trouble with structs and am stuck here :disappointed:

I have some code of the following nature:

```struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)```

Now, I want to add a boolean arguement to the struct. I added a 'neighbors' parameter and came up with this:


```struct BlockPartition{Dim,T, neighbors = false} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
  neighbors::Bool
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors}(sides, neighbors)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition(sides, neighbors)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
  Dim = embeddim(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
  calculate_metadata = method.neighbors```

However it doesn't seem to be working. I suspect the problem lies in the following lines:


`BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)`

`BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)`

However I am not sure how to change them. How can I go about doing this?
I get the following error:

elements.text:
Hey everyone!
I'm having some trouble with structs and am stuck here
I have some code of the following nature:

struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
Dim = embeddim(object)
  T = coordtype(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
Now, I want to add a boolean arguement to the struct. I added a 'neighbors' parameter and came up with this:

struct BlockPartition{Dim,T, neighbors = false} <: PartitionMethod
  sides::SVector{Dim,T}
  neighbors::Bool
end

BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition{Dim,T,neighbors}(sides, neighbors)

BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}, neighbors::Bool) where {Dim,T,neighbors} = BlockPartition(sides, neighbors)

function partition(object, method::BlockPartition)
  Dim = embeddim(object)

  psides = method.sides
  bbox = boundingbox(object)
  calculate_metadata = method.neighbors
However it doesn't seem to be working. I suspect the problem lies in the following lines:
BlockPartition(sides::NTuple{Dim,T}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides)
BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(sides)

However I am not sure how to change them. How can I go about doing this?
I get the following error:

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/56664| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
I think you might misunderstand how parameters work. What you want here is an inner constructor

elements.text: I think you might misunderstand how parameters work. What you want here is an inner constructor

text:
```julia> struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
         sides::SVector{Dim,T}
         neighbors::Bool
         BlockPartition(sides::SVector{Dim,T}, neighbors = false) where {Dim,T} = new{Dim,T}(sides, neighbors)
       end

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3))
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3),true)
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], true)

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3),false)
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)```

elements.text:
julia> struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
         sides::SVector{Dim,T}
         neighbors::Bool
         BlockPartition(sides::SVector{Dim,T}, neighbors = false) where {Dim,T} = new{Dim,T}(sides, neighbors)
       end

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3))
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3),true)
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], true)

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3),false)
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)

text:
You could do it as an outer constructor as well:
```julia> struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
           sides::SVector{Dim,T}
           neighbors::Bool
       end

julia> BlockPartition(sides::SVector{Dim,T}, neighbors = false) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides, neighbors)
BlockPartition

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3),false)
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3))
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)```

elements.text: You could do it as an outer constructor as well:

julia> struct BlockPartition{Dim,T} <: PartitionMethod
           sides::SVector{Dim,T}
           neighbors::Bool
       end

julia> BlockPartition(sides::SVector{Dim,T}, neighbors = false) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition{Dim,T}(sides, neighbors)
BlockPartition

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3),false)
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)

julia> BlockPartition(SVector{3,UInt8}(1,2,3))
BlockPartition{3,UInt8}(UInt8[0x01, 0x02, 0x03], false)

text: but `neighbors = false` belongs in the constructor... not as a type parameter

elements.text: but
neighbors = false
belongs in the constructor... not as a type parameter

text:
<@USU9FRPEU> This was originally an implementation of BlockPartition in Meshes.jl, which is also a part of GeoStats.jl.
I wanted to add the neighbors boolean arguement as an optional keyword which will allow the user to disable a particular calculation.
When I tried to use the inner constructor mentioned above, it still did not calculate the block partitions for a training image from GeoStatsImages.jl (more specifically, the 'WalkerLakeTruth' image).
I tried the outer method constructor, inspired from what you shared, as well:

elements.text:
This was originally an implementation of BlockPartition in Meshes.jl, which is also a part of GeoStats.jl.
I wanted to add the neighbors boolean arguement as an optional keyword which will allow the user to disable a particular calculation.
When I tried to use the inner constructor mentioned above, it still did not calculate the block partitions for a training image from GeoStatsImages.jl (more specifically, the 'WalkerLakeTruth' image).
I tried the outer method constructor, inspired from what you shared, as well:

text: Well you cannot have a `Vararg` and follow it by a positional variable. Try it as a keyword argument?

elements.text: Well you cannot have a
Vararg
and follow it by a positional variable. Try it as a keyword argument?

text:
I put it as a keyword arguement earliier on for the 'partition' function, however the maintainer's want me to shift the boolean arguement to the constructor itself

Would it make sense to shift the boolean arguement to the beginning of where we're defining the parameters?

elements.text:
I put it as a keyword arguement earliier on for the 'partition' function, however the maintainer's want me to shift the boolean arguement to the constructor itself

Would it make sense to shift the boolean arguement to the beginning of where we're defining the parameters?

text:
```julia> BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}; neighbors::Bool = false) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(SVector(sides), neighbors)
BlockPartition

julia> BlockPartition(1,2,3)
BlockPartition{3,Int64}([1, 2, 3], false)

julia> BlockPartition(1,2,3; neighbors = true)
BlockPartition{3,Int64}([1, 2, 3], true)

julia> BlockPartition(1,2,3; neighbors = false)
BlockPartition{3,Int64}([1, 2, 3], false)```

elements.text:
julia> BlockPartition(sides::Vararg{T,Dim}; neighbors::Bool = false) where {Dim,T} = BlockPartition(SVector(sides), neighbors)
BlockPartition

julia> BlockPartition(1,2,3)
BlockPartition{3,Int64}([1, 2, 3], false)

julia> BlockPartition(1,2,3; neighbors = true)
BlockPartition{3,Int64}([1, 2, 3], true)

julia> BlockPartition(1,2,3; neighbors = false)
BlockPartition{3,Int64}([1, 2, 3], false)

text: There's a difference between the type parameters and keyword arguments. You are trying to parameterize value not type. It does not belong with the type parameters.

elements.text: There's a difference between the type parameters and keyword arguments. You are trying to parameterize value not type. It does not belong with the type parameters.

text:
When I try to call BlockPartition with a boolean arguement, for example `B1 = partition(P, BlockPartition(50.,50.,true))`, which is what the maintainers are looking for. It is only working if I don't specify a boolean parameter, which leads me to believe that it is assigning `false` to `neighbors` since that is what we defined as the default,
How do I vary `neighbors`?
Additionally, the print statements that I added for debugging are not working either.
